data.text:
Hi,

Atlas MFB Mill Arbors

How are these 2 arbors used?

Does 'A' use a cutter with slot/holes that are locked into the 2 pins??

If 'B' gets held in with the drawbar how are the 2 slots used??

Thanks

at

For the long arbor, the nose of the spindle SHOULD have a driver screwed to the face of the spindle. That driver has two pins similar to your Shell Mill Arbor.

The pins engage the slots on the collar of the B arbor.

YES, for the A Shell Mill driver/ arbor. You find a tool that has slots just like the B has, and hold that tool in place with the washer and screw.

I kinda' thought something was missing for the long one.

I don't have the machine anymore. The new owner is telling me that

the drawbar is tight but the arbor is loose. If you use a spindle nose ''pinned driver'' adaptor

wouldn't that make the drawbar tighten the arbor against the spindle but the

mt2 would not be seated?? I'm guessing this is OK since the arbor is supported on the other end??

Thanks

Yes the nose support bracket is a must. Dont use the arbor with out it

GP

On Tuesday, December 8, 2020, 11:35:11 AM EST, angelo via groups.io <angelo4967@...> wrote:

Forgot to mention, with the ''extinct'' 1''-10tpi spindle thread where would you even find that adaptor??

If the drawbar is tight but the arbor is loose, then the drawbar is too long. It should be short enough that it pulls the arbor tight into the Morse taper socket before the threads bottom out. Or, maybe, the taper has been reamed out too large for the arbor.

If he is using just an end mill, he can probably get away without the “pinned driver” adaptor. The Morse taper will take quite a bit of torque. For a large cutter, though, he should use the adaptor.

All other shanks with an mt2 taper are fine with the drawbar.

I've got to find out if the 3/8''-16 thread in the taper end of the arbor is OK.

I'm not sure A is a toolholding arbor. It may be a pulley holder to drive something like the Marvin vertical milling head, or something else entire.

I have two of arbor B, one in 7/8" & the other is, IIRC, 1-1/4". I've been a couple months from having my MF running for many years now.

I did buy an MT2 to ER32 chuck for holding endmills, and it is about as short as your arbor A. It would only be useable on stuff clamped to an angle plate, I believe. There is an extract from Popular Mechanics in files about using endmills on the Atlas mills, and reading that is as close to experience using a horizontal mill.

I have used vertical mills, Bridgeport clones, but not a horizontal, so far.

HTH!

Bill in OKC

at

If arbor B is held in with the drawbar, I'm thinking a threaded collar on the spindle

pushing against a ''2 pinned'' sliding collar into the 2 slots on the arbor to really lock it in.

OR........ what are the 2 slots for??

I don't think this little mill can spin an mt2 taper unless you run it past it's limits.

at

Charles had it right - the first is a Shell Arbor and there should be a screwed nose fitting (with drive pins) for the "long" arbour.

I find the problem with the MT2 taper is that it's easy to 'overdo' the drawbar and then have problems getting the tool out. My Clarkson collet chuck has a screwed body piece that let's you 'pull' the chuck out without having to hammer the drawbar end - which helps.

Whilst I do have a vertical head for my MF, it has no quill, so I sometimes use the Mill for milling & drilling in 'jig-boring' mode sometimes

Regards,

IanT

I doubt that you can find that adaptor.

Probably have to make one.

Photos of set up, I recently acquired.

They require different size spacers on the draw bar.

- Bob, Tucson

You would be a brave man to run that setup!

Cheers

John B

My preferred method for freeing stuck / sticky arbors in the milling spindle is to bring the table hard up against the spindle collar (leave the drawbar in the arbor) and give the drawbar a short sharp wack from behind.

Works for me.

Cheers

John B
